subject: Re: JUnit vs Regression Testing
msgSnippet: Hi Jorg Thanks for your response. But by executing these test-suites repeatedly am I not exactly performing a Regression Test ? I ensure that the old code is
messageBody:
Hi Jorg

Thanks for your response.
But by executing these test-suites repeatedly am I not exactly
performing a Regression Test ? I ensure that the old code is not
broken and at the same time I test the new modifications also.
Kindly correct if I am wrong.

Even JUnit is described as a Regession Testing framework and I had
some posts earlier in this group which confirmed that.

Thanks
Anand

--- In junit@y..., "Schaible, Jorg" <joerg.schaible@g...> wrote:
> Hi Anand,
>
> this something totally different. Have a look at eXtreme
Porgramming und
> unit testing. The idea is to write unit tests before writing the
actual
> code. This implies that you have defined your results first and
implement
> your class/interface along this "specification". Although I admit
that most
> programmers will write there unit tests after coding. Nevertheless
is unit
> testing always a white box test done by the programmer ensuring
that changes
> in the code will not break functionality other modules may rely on.
>
> Regression tests are a completly different beast.
>
> Greetings,
> Jorg
>
> >-----Original Message-----
> >From: anand_73@y... [mailto:anand_73@y...]
> >Sent: Thursday, August 23, 2001 6:27 AM
> >To: junit@y...
> >Subject: [junit] JUnit vs Regression Testing
> >
> >
> >Hi
> >
> >I would like to clarify one thing.
> >When a commercial tool is used to test a product,it records the
> >results from the first test run and compares it when we run again
(
> >Regression Testing ).
> >
> >How do we actually do this with JUnit ?
> >
> >Thanks
> >Anand
> >
> >
